snippet.textDisplay:
_o_ Jeremy Soule _o_

Love his work, from his well known work like Skyrim and Guild Wars to his earlier work on Total Annihilation and Secret of Evermore. It's all beautiful.
He's currently working on his very own symphony, titled "The Northerner". Release date is TBA, but I'm looking forward to it!
snippet.textOriginal:
_o_ Jeremy Soule _o_

Love his work, from his well known work like Skyrim and Guild Wars to his earlier work on Total Annihilation and Secret of Evermore. It's all beautiful.
He's currently working on his very own symphony, titled "The Northerner". Release date is TBA, but I'm looking forward to it!

snippet.textDisplay: This game is a masterpiece. I've invested way too much time in it, but it's seriously just that good. All the attention to detail makes it one of my favorite games of all time, and IMO one of the best games ever. Come to think of it, the same can be said for almost all of the TES games.
snippet.textOriginal: This game is a masterpiece. I've invested way too much time in it, but it's seriously just that good. All the attention to detail makes it one of my favorite games of all time, and IMO one of the best games ever. Come to think of it, the same can be said for almost all of the TES games.

snippet.textDisplay:
I personally think this may be the best game I have ever played and know of. The music and story was amazing, and sure the voice acting was rusty due to a severely low amount of voice actors, but the asthetics of this and all the rest of the game make it amazing. Skyrim was hard to enjoy even with dlc but with Oblivion I could enjoy the whole game on its own.
I play this on my day 1 Xbox360 and it still works with a midnight launch copy of oblivion. I just want to say if this was backwards compatible on Xbox 1, I would worship Todd Howard for that and I would not be able to sleep at all or simple be able to actually sleep. This game was perfectly made and it proves it, if only it were as praised as Skyrim.
snippet.textOriginal:
I personally think this may be the best game I have ever played and know of. The music and story was amazing, and sure the voice acting was rusty due to a severely low amount of voice actors, but the asthetics of this and all the rest of the game make it amazing. Skyrim was hard to enjoy even with dlc but with Oblivion I could enjoy the whole game on its own.
I play this on my day 1 Xbox360 and it still works with a midnight launch copy of oblivion. I just want to say if this was backwards compatible on Xbox 1, I would worship Todd Howard for that and I would not be able to sleep at all or simple be able to actually sleep. This game was perfectly made and it proves it, if only it were as praised as Skyrim.

snippet.textDisplay:
A lot of people don't like how simple Oblivion made questing, and hate 
Skyrim because it's so easy to get things done. Back in the Morrowind 
and Daggerfall days, you didn't get icons on your map telling you where 
to go and who to talk to. You actually had to chat up townsfolk, ask 
about people you were looking for, and half the time the person you were
 talking to would have no idea where they are. Even if they did know, it
 would usually be something vague, or directions to /another/ person who
 was better acquainted with whoever you really wanted to talk to. The 
worlds were more alive. Still a great soundtrack though.
snippet.textOriginal:
A lot of people don't like how simple Oblivion made questing, and hate 
Skyrim because it's so easy to get things done. Back in the Morrowind 
and Daggerfall days, you didn't get icons on your map telling you where 
to go and who to talk to. You actually had to chat up townsfolk, ask 
about people you were looking for, and half the time the person you were
 talking to would have no idea where they are. Even if they did know, it
 would usually be something vague, or directions to /another/ person who
 was better acquainted with whoever you really wanted to talk to. The 
worlds were more alive. Still a great soundtrack though.

snippet.textDisplay: It might just be me, but the lack of voiceover in Morrowind was one of the things that made it kinda hard for me to play it. I would usually just skip through all the dialogues and re-read the journal if I missed something crucial. Other than that, the world seemed kinda dark to me (visually) all the time and I really craved mods but since I have a crappy PC, that's a no-go.
snippet.textOriginal: It might just be me, but the lack of voiceover in Morrowind was one of the things that made it kinda hard for me to play it. I would usually just skip through all the dialogues and re-read the journal if I missed something crucial. Other than that, the world seemed kinda dark to me (visually) all the time and I really craved mods but since I have a crappy PC, that's a no-go.

snippet.textDisplay: I have Oblivion and Skyrim for PS3.  I bought them without high hopes and they blew me away.  I got Oblivion first and it was amazing.  Skyrim impressed me with its controls and game play but Oblivion still seems like a larger world for some reason.  I felt that I have explored most of Skyrim after a short while but only touched Oblivion.
snippet.textOriginal: I have Oblivion and Skyrim for PS3.  I bought them without high hopes and they blew me away.  I got Oblivion first and it was amazing.  Skyrim impressed me with its controls and game play but Oblivion still seems like a larger world for some reason.  I felt that I have explored most of Skyrim after a short while but only touched Oblivion.

snippet.textDisplay: I knew there was a reason why I hated Oblivion, and didn't give it much time. Thanks for reminding me! The levelling system was indeed atrocious, and in fact completely broken beyond repair. And I'm one of those awful people who judges a game vanilla, without looking to the modding community to fix it when the developers screw up.
snippet.textOriginal: I knew there was a reason why I hated Oblivion, and didn't give it much time. Thanks for reminding me! The levelling system was indeed atrocious, and in fact completely broken beyond repair. And I'm one of those awful people who judges a game vanilla, without looking to the modding community to fix it when the developers screw up.

snippet.textDisplay: The biggest flaw in my mind was Oblivion's leveling system. Unless you power leveled every time, which I definitely didn't know to do until far too late in the game, the harder difficulties make enemies far more powerful than the player, which creates a very frustrating experience. Otherwise, I thoroughly enjoyed the hell out of the this game and it's world. The Dark Brotherhood storyline in probably one of my favorite storylines in gaming.
snippet.textOriginal: The biggest flaw in my mind was Oblivion's leveling system. Unless you power leveled every time, which I definitely didn't know to do until far too late in the game, the harder difficulties make enemies far more powerful than the player, which creates a very frustrating experience. Otherwise, I thoroughly enjoyed the hell out of the this game and it's world. The Dark Brotherhood storyline in probably one of my favorite storylines in gaming.

snippet.textDisplay: +Dark Assassin9001 A lot of people don't like how simple Oblivion made questing, and hate Skyrim because it's so easy to get things done. Back in the Morrowind and Daggerfall days, you didn't get icons on your map telling you where to go and who to talk to. You actually had to chat up townsfolk, ask about people you were looking for, and half the time the person you were talking to would have no idea where they are. Even if they did know, it would usually be something vague, or directions to /another/ person who was better acquainted with whoever you really wanted to talk to. The worlds were more alive. I totally agree with Will.
snippet.textOriginal: +Dark Assassin9001 A lot of people don't like how simple Oblivion made questing, and hate Skyrim because it's so easy to get things done. Back in the Morrowind and Daggerfall days, you didn't get icons on your map telling you where to go and who to talk to. You actually had to chat up townsfolk, ask about people you were looking for, and half the time the person you were talking to would have no idea where they are. Even if they did know, it would usually be something vague, or directions to /another/ person who was better acquainted with whoever you really wanted to talk to. The worlds were more alive. I totally agree with Will.

snippet.textDisplay: The Skyrim OST is epic and the game itself is awesome, no doubt about that. But this game? This soundtrack? I actually literally fell in love with this game. I had the same feelings for when I played it, that I have had with my girlfriends. When I was at work, I missed it all the time and all I could think of was to come home and play it. I wish I could marry a game.

I wish I could marry a game.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think Oblivion might be my favourite game, this track reminds me of the game so vividly, especially exploring. 

There's something about game music that I find unique, specifically how loosely they can tie to the action, there's a lot of room for interpretation and how they fit the atmosphere.

I think Oblivion might be my favourite game, this track reminds me of the game so vividly, especially exploring.

snippet.textDisplay: @TheRitchardgaleHater True, but the oblivion world felt smaller because it was more monotonous. In morrowind you had a ridiculous amounts of different cultures, environments, and other variables. For example, the different houses in Morrowind built buildings differently, making it so that no city truly looked the same. Also, in Morrowind you can go from a swamp to a desert and everything in between incluing a forest of giant mushrooms in between. In oblivion you dont have that variety.
snippet.textOriginal: @TheRitchardgaleHater True, but the oblivion world felt smaller because it was more monotonous. In morrowind you had a ridiculous amounts of different cultures, environments, and other variables. For example, the different houses in Morrowind built buildings differently, making it so that no city truly looked the same. Also, in Morrowind you can go from a swamp to a desert and everything in between incluing a forest of giant mushrooms in between. In oblivion you dont have that variety.

snippet.textDisplay: An absolutley wonderful game to be sure, but I was just a tiny bit disappointed seeing as that this game cam e right after that masterpiece known as Morrowind. The story line was simpler, the world was smaller and less in-depth, and the art design was not nearly as unique and interesting. Still, oblivion is one of my favorite games on the PC.
snippet.textOriginal: An absolutley wonderful game to be sure, but I was just a tiny bit disappointed seeing as that this game cam e right after that masterpiece known as Morrowind. The story line was simpler, the world was smaller and less in-depth, and the art design was not nearly as unique and interesting. Still, oblivion is one of my favorite games on the PC.

snippet.textDisplay:
@sora8711 
Yeah very different gameplay, in fact a lot of people disregard Fallout 3 as a Fallout.  Fallout 3 was good if it was it's own title but a good Fallout game.  But I guess once Bethesda got it's hands it, they had to put the Oblivion style to it.
snippet.textOriginal:
@sora8711 
Yeah very different gameplay, in fact a lot of people disregard Fallout 3 as a Fallout.  Fallout 3 was good if it was it's own title but a good Fallout game.  But I guess once Bethesda got it's hands it, they had to put the Oblivion style to it.

snippet.textDisplay: This game was great in every single way except it had one fundamental game breaking flaw.  The ability to go 100%camoflauge and basically become immortal against EVERY SINGLE THING IN THE GAME.  And you can get full camo 20% into the game.  It's kind of silly, enemies (and I mean every single enemy in the game) will just sit there and let you sit there indefinitely and beat them to death.  If they removed the ability to get 100% camoflage this game would be truly as good as it deserves to be.
snippet.textOriginal: This game was great in every single way except it had one fundamental game breaking flaw.  The ability to go 100%camoflauge and basically become immortal against EVERY SINGLE THING IN THE GAME.  And you can get full camo 20% into the game.  It's kind of silly, enemies (and I mean every single enemy in the game) will just sit there and let you sit there indefinitely and beat them to death.  If they removed the ability to get 100% camoflage this game would be truly as good as it deserves to be.
